descriptionSet.description: This image shows a redhaired woman in a white dress and a white fur next to two different cigarette boxes. Her hair is tied back into a bun and she is wearing a necklace as well as earrings.

inscription.text: Rothmans De Luxe Pall Mall [ma]de in Eng[land]

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: Rothmans De Luxe Virginia
text-en: Rothmans De Luxe Pall Mall [ma]de in Eng[land]
text-en: made in England

description-en: This image shows a redhaired woman in a white dress and a white fur next to two different cigarette boxes. Her hair is tied back into a bun and she is wearing a necklace as well as earrings.
explanatory comments/crosstagging: /20080627_1722.jpg
explanatory comments/crosstagging: Blonde hair as well as red hair is a distinctive visual marker on advertising images for being Western and therefore an exclusive marker for whiteness. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In the first half of the 20th century far less women smoked cigarettes. Therefore many tobacco ads deliberately targeted women with an advertising rhetoric which attempted to convince females that smoking cigarettes gave them elegance and style. See the project of Tim Coyle: http://otal.umd.edu/~vg/amst205.S97/vj05/cigad.html, last accessed 2011-08-21. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In the Indian context cigarette advertising during almost the entire 20th century featured distinctively Western woman as it was considered to be indecent for Indian woman to smoke in public. Depicting an Indian woman on an ad for cigarettes would most likely have had a negative effect. See also the article on early Indian advertsing by Javeer Masood on Tasveerghar. (la)
related literature: Loyo, Hilaria 2007. "Blinding Blondes: Whiteness, Femininity, and Stardom." In W.Everett (Ed.): Questions of Colour in Cinema, Frankfurt/M etc.: Peter Lang: 179-196. (la)
